Oronite Technology Division, Chevran Research and Technology Company, 100 Chevron Way, Richmond, CA 94802-0627, USA b Instituto de lnvestigaciones en Cat6lisis y Petroquhnica, (INCAPE) FIQ-UNL-CONICET, Santiago del Estero 2654, (3000) Santa Fe. Argentina Chemical Reactor Engineering Centre, Faculo' o['Engineering Science, Department o]" Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, The University o[" Western Ontario, London, Ontario, N6A 5B9, Canada Received 8 July 1994; revised 28 November 1994: accepted 29 November 1994 Abstract Three Zn-Cr mixed oxide plus ZSM-5 compound catalysts with different compositions covering a wide range of Zn/Cr atomic ratios (0.064 to 1.913), aimed at the direct conversion of synthesis gas into hydrocarbons, were tested under different experimental conditions: temperature ranged from 356 to 410, pressure from 3.60 to 4.49 MPa and space velocity from 0.2 to 3.0 mmol reactants/(gcat rain). Reaction products included carbon dioxide, water and hydrocarbons with methanol conversion (through which hydrocarbons are formed) being complete. The catalyst with the least content of zinc gave the highest yields of liquid hydrocarbons (up to 74% of total hydrocarbons). Different crystalline phases (ZnO, ZnCr204 and Cr203) were found in the methanol synthesis component as a function of Zn/Cr ratio. The low Zn/Cr catalyst was characterized by X-ray diffraction, differential thermal analysis, nitrogen adsorption, temperature-programmed reduction, Infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The only phases observed in this catalyst were ZnCr204 and Cr203. Calcination tem- perature had an influence in both physical and chemical catalyst properties. After calcination, Crw and Crm species could be seen on the catalyst surface, but only Crm species were observed after reaction or reduction. The evidences gathered suggest that Cr203 is mainly responsible for methanol synthesis, while ZnCr204 contributes to increase the specific surface area of the catalyst and influences gas product distributions. Compound catalysts with the mixed oxide (Zn-Cr) as the methanol syn- thesis component showed to be more active than those with the individual (Cr or Zn) oxides. Introduction The direct conversion of synthesis gas into hydrocarbons, with methanol syn- thesis as an intermediate step, has been approached with different purposes such as the production of aromatic hydrocarbon mixtures [ 1-4], or the production of different hydrocarbon cuts like, for example, C3 and C4 aikanes [5]. By eliminating methanol production as a separate step, some of the drawbacks of the methanol-to-gasoline (MTG) process (e.g. unfavourable economics) could be circumvented. The catalysts employed consisted of a mixture of two components: a methanol synthesis catalyst (MSC) and a hydrocarbons-from-methanol catalyst. While the second component is an acidic solid (e.g. zeolites H-Y or H-ZSM-5, or SAPO), the MSC formulation can change widely. In fact, a number of different MSCs has been used, including Pd/SiO2 [4] and, especially, an extensive series of Zn-Cr mixed oxides [6,7], which are the catalysts for methanol synthesis conducted at high temperatures ( above 370 ) and high pressures ( about 30 MPa). The choice of the MSC was based on the thermal compatibilities of both compo- nents. In previous works in our laboratories the production of hydrocarbons from synthesis gas was approached using catalyst pellets composed of Zn-Cr mixed oxides and zeolite ZSM-5 [8]. The reaction was carried out successfully in a continuous process development unit using a special reactor configuration aimed at operating the unit under the pseudoadiabatic regime [ 9,10]. The pseudoadiabatic operation of fixed bed reactors requires the fully co-current cooling of the unit. This operation exhibits a series of intrinsic advantages like, for example, the continuously increasing temperature profile locating the maximum temperature at the reactor exit, and the low parametric sensitivity. These facts have also been confirmed in an industrial unit [ 11 ]. In the particular case of the direct conversion of synthesis gas into hydrocarbons, it was possible to achieve a strong 'drain-off' effect on the thermodynamic limitations of the methanol synthesis. The 'drain-off' effect allowed to operate the unit at relatively low pressures (2-3 MPa) [8]. Although they take part of a well established technology [12], there has been a renewed interest in Zn-Cr mixed oxides MSCs due to the possibility of using them for the production of higher alcohols, which may constitute valuable chemicals [ 13 ]. Consequently, a number of papers has been published recently that deal with Zn-Cr mixed oxides MSC characterization and the role played by the various component phases (e.g. [ 14,15] ). However, most of the research work has been performed on a Zn/Cr atomic ratio range over 0.5. It is the objective of this paper to report, in Section 3.1, the catalytic performance of a series of Zn-Cr mixed oxides plus ZSM-5 catalysts in the direct conversion of synthesis gas into hydrocarbons. The ratio between the two components was kept constant, while the composition of the MSC was changed covering a wide range. The screening process focused on the optimization of liquid hydrocarbon yields. The best composition for the MSC was found to be the one with the lowest zinc F. Simard et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 81-98 83 content (Zn/Cr= 0.064). This catalyst was characterized by different techniques such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), differential thermal analysis (DTA), N2 adsorp- tion, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), infrared (IR) and X-ray photo- electron spectroscopy (XPS), and the results are presented in Section 3.2 of the paper. An identification of the active species was also attempted. 2. Experimental The Zn-Cr mixed oxides MSCs were synthesized by co-precipitation, starting from a mixture of solutions of the zinc and chromium nitrates at 80 and adding a solution of NH4OH to produce precipitation. Typical synthesis steps included co- precipitation, washing with deionized water, drying at 110 (dried precursor), and calcination at different temperatures for five hours. Pure Cr203 and ZnO sam- ples were generated and treated in a similar way. Three samples of MSC + ZSM-5 with different Zn/Cr atomic ratios were pre- pared. The observed values, as measured by X-ray fluorescence were 1.913 (MSC in Catalyst A), 0.557 (MSC in Catalyst B) and 0.064 (MSC in Catalyst C), respectively. The zeolite ZSM-5 was synthesized according to the technique of Gabelica et al. [16], with a SiO2/A1203 ratio of 42. Finally, cylindrical pellets of the compound catalyst ( 1 / 8 in. size) were prepared by extrusion with 63 wt.-% methanol synthesis catalyst, 27 wt.-% zeolite and 10 wt.-% fused AI203 binder (Versal 950, Kaiser Chemicals) with extra water added to produce a paste. All catalysts were dried at 110. Calcination was typically performed at 350 during 5 h. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected in a Rigaku Horizontal Dif- fractometer, using Cu Ka radiation. Identification of crystalline phases was based on standard references published by the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (1974). A pure Cr203 sample (BDH) was used as a reference to compare against observed XRD spectra. Differential thermal analyses were done with a Shimadzu DT-80 analyzer using a 1.86% O2 in N2 stream with a heating rate of 20 min- J. Dried precursor samples without further treatments were used; A1203 was used as a reference. Physical properties were determined by standard nitrogen adsorption BET pro- cedure, with a Micromeritics Acusorb 2100 equipment. Temperature-programmed reduction experiments were performed in a flow appa- ratus under the following conditions: gas, 5% H2 in N2; flow, 9 ml min- 1; linear heating rate, 6 min ~ starting at room temperature. The samples were previously dried 'in situ' for 2 h at 150 under nitrogen stream. Infrared spectra were collected using a Perkin Elmer model 580B spectrometer on samples prepared by the KBr technique; wafers were prepared under ambient air, containing 1% of catalyst previously pretreated under different conditions, and 84 F. Simard et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 81 98 then transferred to the cell. The samples were calcined and reduced at different temperatures. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyses were done on a SSL Surface Science Laboratory ESCA Spectrometer, Model SSX-100. Activity runs were performed in a 7.62 cm I.D. Betty reactor. The original basket volume was reduced to a 2.54 cm diameter and 5.08 cm height basket by means of an aluminum insert, in order to accommodate small samples of catalyst. The tem- perature of the system was controlled using two thermocouples (chromel-alumel junction, 1.5 ram) located at the two extremities of the catalytic bed (top and bottom of the bed). The gas fed was controlled using mass flow controllers ( Brooks 5850 series). Conditions for the runs ranged in temperature from 356 to 410, in pressure from 3.60 to 4.50 MPa and in space velocity from 0.2 to 3.0 mmol/(g min) of HR/CO mixtures with molar ratio 1. Reaction products were analyzed by combined gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. A drierite trap and an oxy-trap were used to eliminate traces of water and oxygen, respectively. The pressure in the system was maintained with a Tescom back pressure regulator model 26-3200, equipped with a high-temperature polyamide seat (Vespel, Dupont). The product stream, maintained at 250, was depressurized to atmospheric pressure before flowing through a heated six ports Valco valve equipped with a 1 ml loop, for on- line gas chromatographic analysis. Liquid samples were collected in a trap immersed in a water-ice bath. The flow-rate of the non-condensed products was measured with a bubble flowmeter. Additional details about the experimental sys- tem used for the activity runs are reported by Simard et al. [ 17]. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Catalytic activity and selectiviO' of compound catalysts with different Zn/Cr ratios in the MSC component The influence of the composition of the MSC on the conversion of synthesis gas into hydrocarbons is shown in Table 1. These catalysts samples, not subjected to a pre-reduction, gave carbon monoxide conversions increasing with the zinc content. This behaviour has also been reported in other works with Zn-Cr catalysts [ 6,18] and is also in line with the fact that high-pressure industrial Zn-Cr MSCs show Zn/Cr ratios in the order of 3. ZnO was considered to be the active phase in these types of catalysts [ 19]; however, other studies (e.g. ref. [20] ), postulate that octahedrally coordinated, excess zinc atoms inside the non-stoichiometric ZnCr204 spinel in a system ZnO- ZnCr204, are the active sites for the synthesis of methanol, while the stoichiometric ZnCr204 (Zn/Cr= 0.5) spinel is inactive. Catalyst deactivation is an important characteristic of these catalysts. For exam- ple, the carbon monoxide conversion found with Catalyst C at 0 and 360 min time- on-stream were 22.9 and 14.5%, respectively. Catalyst activity in all the cases, after an initial decrease, became stabilized. This deactivation with time-on-stream, as described by Simard et ah [ 17], reflects a transition from initial catalytic activity to steady-state values. This deactivation is much milder for pre-reduced catalysts, case of Catalyst C. Also catalysts with a higher zinc content (e.g. Catalyst A of Table 1 ) appear to be less affected by the deactivation phenomenon. Concerning Catalyst C, the one yielding higher C~ + fractions, it was observed that kinetic constants for synthesis gas conversion had an initial exponential decay with time-on-stream, becoming stable after this initial drop. This behaviour was also observed for the same type of catalyst under pseudoadiabatic operation [ 8 ]. Because of the enhanced selectivity towards production of C5-C~2 hydrocarbons over Catalyst C, the effect of reaction conditions was studied further with this catalyst. Upon increasing the reaction temperature from 356 to 410 at a synthesis gas flow-rate of 2.9 mmol/(g rain), the steady-state carbon monoxide conversion level increased from 4% to 11%, respectively, while the proportion of liquid hydro- carbons decreases (92.0% and 74.6% for 356 and 4100C, respectively). There is, however, a noticeable increase in hydrogenation activity, as shown by the higher amounts of light alkanes C2-C4 (most of the C4 products are alkanes). This is in accordance with Yashima et al. [ 1 ], who also noted a decrease in aromatic selec- tivity when increasing the temperature from 284 to 344. As expected, carbon monoxide conversion and aromatic selectivity increase significantly as a function of contact time. Results presented so far were obtained on catalysts that were not pre-reduced contacting them with synthesis gas at reaction temperature. The important effect of the pretreatment conditions on catalyst performance is shown in Table 2. The samples were heated slowly (<5/min) to 300 and maintained at this tem- perature for 16 h under a slightly pressurized (close to ambient pressure) stream of 7.8% H2 in He. It can be observed that only the catalyst pre-reduced with 7.8% H2 in He showed important conversions at 410 and 3.60 MPa. On this basis it can be argued that catalysts, such as Catalyst C, not being subjected to mild pre- reduction conditions and being directly exposed to the synthesis gas mixture may experience some kind of thermal shock, given the exothermicity of the reduction reaction. Moreover, the catalysts employed for these experiments also incorporated a binder to obtain pellets which had enough attrition resistance so as to be used in the pilot plant size pseudoadiabatic reactor [ 8 ]. This could be associated to the sharp decrease in catalyst surface area when the calcination temperature is increased. Carbon monoxide conversion increased substantially and hydrocarbon selectivity decreased slightly, what pro- duced a sharp increase in hydrocarbon yield. It is interesting to point out that liquid hydrocarbon product distribution remained essentially the same while it is evident that the pre-reduced compound catalyst had a somewhat higher hydrogenation activity, which is reflected in the increased amount of light alkanes. In view of the higher liquid hydrocarbons production of the catalyst having the lowest Zn/Cr, even though carbon monoxide conversion was lower when compared with catalysts with higher Zn/Cr ratios, emphasis was given to the characterization of its MSC component. Characterization of the MSC in Catalyst C The very low Zn/Cr ratio (0.064) constitutes a very distinctive property of the catalyst which produced the highest liquid hydrocarbons yield. Previous work on synthesis gas conversion to hydrocarbons with Zn-Cr-zeolite catalysts [ 1,6,7] and Zn-Cr-amorphous silica-alumina [ 23 ], as well as works dealing with MSCs char- acterization [ 14,24] or even catalyst development for associated reactions such as higher alcohols synthesis [ 24], were all developed on catalysts with much higher Zn/Cr ratios, typically above 0.5. Crystalline phases present: influence of the calcination temperature Samples of the dried precursor of the MSC were calcined at 280, 300, 350,400, 450, 500 and 550 to study the influence of calcination temperature. Some of the corresponding powder XRD spectra are presented in Fig. 2. With the exception of the dried precursor and the samples calcined at 280 and 300, which appeared to be insufficient to induce crystallization, all the other samples did show very clear and sharp peaks that can be unambiguously assigned to Cr203. Moreover, the XRD spectrum of a pure CreO3 powder sample was done to confirm the assignments, giving exactly the same spectrum without the ZnCr204 spinel peaks. The computer simulation of the XRD spectrum of the sample calcined at 500 was done taking into account the Zn/Cr atomic ratio of 0.064 and assuming that only Cr203 and ZnCr204 were present in the catalyst. The resulting XRD computer- simulated spectrum was essentially the same as the one observed experimentally. It has to be mentioned that, so far, no report in the technical literature has been published on the crystalline properties of Zn-Cr mixed oxides with very low Zn/ Cr ratios. The lowest Zn/Cr ratio for Zn-Cr mixed oxides, with a powder XRD spectrum reported, was 0.5 [ 14]. In the case of our study when 0.5 < Zn/Cr < 1.0, the catalyst only showed a single crystalline phase, ZnCr204. It is claimed this phase is non-stoichiometric due to excess zinc in the spinel [14]. As already mentioned, and according to del Piero et al. [20], it is precisely this non-stoichi- ometry which would give catalytic activity to the spinel for methanol synthesis. In contrast, the stoichiometric spinel (Zn/Cr = 0.5) was reported to be inactive. The possibility of excess zinc in the spinel has also been suggested by Williams and Cunningham [ 26 ]. This is certainly the case for the MSC component in our Catalyst B. However, in the case of the MSC component in Catalyst C, there is little ground, due to the very low amounts of zinc, to believe that the ZnCr204 spinel is non- stoichiometric (with excess zinc). Thus, it would not be active in methanol syn- thesis from synthesis gas. In conclusion, the calcination of the Zn-Cr catalyst (Catalyst C) produced a Cr203 phase plus a ZnCr204 spinel phase when the temperature was 350 or higher. Differential thermal analysis Fig. 3 shows the DTA profiles of the dried precursor of the MSC in Catalyst C and a precipitated Cr203 sample, which were performed under an oxygen-nitrogen atmosphere. Both profiles are similar, having two endothermic peaks and one exothermic peak. The endothermic peaks can be assigned to the removal of water bound to the gel with different strength, the first one at about 110-130 and the second one at about 210--230. The exothermic peak at 460 in the case of the CreO3 sample shows the crystallization of the amorphous gel; the same pattern was observed by Bhattacharyya et al. [27]. The exothermic peak is wider and shifted to higher temperatures for the Zn-Cr mixed oxide catalyst. The crystallization of ZnCr204 has been reported to follow an endothermic process above 470 [28] or 525 under inert atmosphere [26]. However, the wider peak and the shift in its location could be ascribed to the interaction between the dominant influence of the enthalpy of Cr203 crystallization, F. It has to be stressed that the formation of crystalline phases was not observed at calcination temperatures lower than 300. Fig. 2 illustrates the absence of crys- talline phases for samples calcined at 280. Physical properties BET surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution analyses were per- formed on selected samples of the MSC component in Catalyst C after treatment under different conditions. Results are presented in Table 3. It can be seen that there was a sharp change in the physical properties of the catalyst (specific surface area and pore volume) as well as an associated destruction of smaller pores when the temperature of calcination increased from 350 to 400 ( see Fig. 4). However, a further increase in temperature ( to 500 ) did not produce such dramatic changes. On the other hand, there was no noticeable change when the reduction temperature was increased from 370 to 450 on catalysts previously calcined at 400. Consequently, calcination temperature appears to have a very important role to produce a high specific surface area catalyst. In this respect, it can be stated that reported specific surface areas for Cr203, which is the main phase in this Zn-Cr mixed oxide catalyst, vary widely as a function of the atmosphere in which the treatment was performed. Conclusions In a series of Zn-Cr mixed oxides, the catalyst with the lowest Zn/Cr atomic ratio (0.064) is the one which produced the highest liquid hydrocarbons yield, although being less active in the direct transformation of synthesis gas to hydro- carbons, on compound Zn-Cr mixed oxide-zeolite catalysts. The MSC component in that catalyst is composed of two phases, Cr203 and ZnCr204. The conversion of synthesis gas to methanol is mainly performed on the Cr203 phase, while the ZnCr204 phase which, if stoichiometric, has been shown to be inactive for methanol synthesis, showed to have a strong influence in the hydrogenation of intermediate alkenes. A positive effect is believed to be exerted by the ZnCr204 spinel in providing a higher specific surface area, as compared with Cr203 alone. Thermal treatments have a profound influence on the catalyst's physical prop- erties, and a minimum temperature, 350, was shown to be necessary for the ZnCr204 spinel and Cr203 to crystallize. Both Crw and C1Jn species are seen on the calcined catalyst surface; however, it is believed that the only chemical state for chromium atoms under reaction conditions is CO~. The catalyst with the mixed oxide (Zn-Cr) as the MSC component showed to be more active than the ones with single (Zn or Cr) oxides only. References [ 1 ] T. Yashima, A. Yoshimura, Y. Three ZnCr mixed oxide plus ZSM-5 compound catalysts with different compositions covering a wide range of Zn/Cr atomic ratios (0.064 to 1.913), aimed at the direct conversion of synthesis gas into hydrocarbons, were tested under different experimental conditions: temperature ranged from 356 to 410°C, pressure from 3.60 to 4.49 MPa and space velocity from 0.2 to 3.0 mmol reactants/(gcat min). Reaction products included carbon dioxide, water and hydrocarbons with methanol conversion (through which hydrocarbons are formed) being complete. The catalyst with the least content of zinc gave the highest yields of liquid hydrocarbons (up to 74% of total hydrocarbons). Different crystalline phases (ZnO, ZnCr2O4 and Cr2O3) were found in the methanol synthesis component as a function of Zn/Cr ratio. The low Zn/Cr catalyst was characterized by X-ray diffraction, differential thermal analysis, nitrogen adsorption, temperature-programmed reduction, Infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The only phases observed in this catalyst were ZnCr2O4 and Cr2O3. Calcination temperature had an influence in both physical and chemical catalyst properties. After calcination, CrVI and CrIII species could be seen on the catalyst surface, but only CrIII species were observed after reaction or reduction. The evidences gathered suggest that Cr2O3 is mainly responsible for methanol synthesis, while ZnCr2O4 contributes to increase the specific surface area of the catalyst and influences gas product distributions. Compound catalysts with the mixed oxide (ZnCr) as the methanol synthesis component showed to be more active than those with the individual (Cr or Zn) oxides.
